11224Structural ChemistryComputational and Experimental Studies of Chemical and Biological SystemsStruct Chem1040-04001572-9001Springer USBostons11224-009-9417-0941710.1007/s11224-009-9417-0Original ResearchA new hetero-bimetallic coordination polymer, cesium, and sodium complex of styphnate trihydrate [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]nLiuJun-Wei1ZhangJian-Guo1bZhangTong-Lai1ZhengHong2YangLi1YuKai-Bei1grid.43555.320000000088416246State Key Laboratory of Explosion Science and TechnologyBeijing Institute of Technology100081BeijingChinaHubei Entry–Exit Inspection and Quarantine Bureau430022WuhanHubeiPeople’s Republic of China+86-10-68913818zhangjianguobit@yahoo.com.cn12220096200920338739216120092210200816120091222009© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20092009Abstract

A new hetero-bimetallic coordination polymer, cesium, and sodium complex of styphnate trihydrate [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n (TNR: 2,4,6-trinitroresorcinol dianion, the dianion of styphnic acid) was synthesized. The title complex was characterized by X-ray single crystal diffraction, element analysis, FT-IR, DSC, TG-DTG studies. In the title polymer molecule, the cesium cation is coordinated by 13 oxygen atoms: three originated from the water molecule and the others are from the nitro group and the phenolic hydroxyl group of TNR; the sodium cation is surrounded by six oxygen atoms from water molecules and TNR forming a distorted octahedron. The coordination polymer crystal was formed by the bridging ligands of water molecules and TNR connected with different cesium and sodium cations.

2,4,6-Trinitro-1,3-benzenediol (2,4,6-trinitro-resorcinol) is also known as styphnic acid. According to its structure, explosive power, and sensitivity, it is similar to picric acid [1]. It and its metal salts are important military and commercial explosive materials. In particular, lead, barium, silver, and potassium salts of 2,4,6-trinitro-resorcinol have good detonating properties and are sensitive to flames and impact, therefore, they can be used as ingredient in the primary explosives, delay composition, ignition composition, and percussion composition [2]. A considerable amount of research about the structure and properties the salts of 2,4,6-trinitro-resorcinol have been done during the last 40 years [3–18].

The previous research works are mainly focused on the heavy metal complex of styphnic acid which is widely used in propellants and primary explosives. However, there are more or less shortcomings with them, such as serious heavy metal pollution and high static sensitivity. In order to explore environment friendly initiating compositions, people gradually emphasized particularly on the alkaline and alkali-earth metal salts of nitrogen-rich acid [17–23]. In our recent research works, we synthesized the potassium, sodium, barium salts of 2,4,6-trinitro-resorcinol and trinitrophloroglucinol, determined their crystal structures [15–19]. Here, we prepared a new hetero-bimetallic complex of styphnate, [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n, cultured its single crystal, determined its molecular structure and crystal structure, put forward a thermal decomposition mechanism of the title compound from DSC, TG-DTG, and FT-IR results.

ExperimentalMaterials and instruments

2,4,6-Trinitro-resorcinol is a commercial product and has been purified by recrystallization in distilled water. Other materials and reagents used in the experiments are analytically pure.

Infrared spectrum was recorded on Bruker Equinox-55 spectrometer in the range of 4000–400 cm−1 using KBr pellets with the resolution of 4 cm−1. Elemental analyses were performed on an 1106 full-automatic trace element analyzer.

The single crystal structure was determined by Siemens P4 diffractometers with graphite-monochromated Mo Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K.

TG-DTG measurements were carried out on a Pyris-1 differential scanning calorimeter and thermogravimeter under nitrogen atmosphere. The heating rate was 10 °C/min for TG. The conditions of DSC were as follows: sample mass about 1.0 mg, heated rate 10 °C/min, static air atmosphere, α-Al2O3 reference sample.

Synthesis of the title compound

Sodium styphnate solution was prepared by slowly adding sodium carbonate (5 mmol) into equivalent diluted aqueous styphnic acid (100 mL, 0.1 mol/L) by heating and agitating at 60 °C for 30 min. After the total reaction, the mixture was cooled and filtered. The obtained liquor was added dropwise into aqueous cesium nitrate solution (50 mL, 0.1 mol/L) with violent stirring. The mixture reacted at 75 °C for 45 min until yellowish precipitate was formed. The precipitate was collected by filtration and washed with distilled water. Dissolve the powder in hot distilled water, filtrate, and then cool the solution to crystallize the final product and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 2 h. A yellowish powder of [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n was obtained in a yield of 65% based styphnic acid.

The yellowish precipitate was recrystallized with distilled water and kept at room temperature for 2 weeks to obtain the single crystals for X-ray measurement.

Anal. Calcd. for C6H7CsN3NaO11: C 15.89, H 1.55, N 9.27, O 38.85%. Found: C 15.91, H 1.45, N 9.32, O 38.79%. IR spectra (KBr, cm−1): 3451 [v (H2O)], 1622, 1473, 1395 [v (the benzene ring framework)], 1526[vas (ph-NO2)], 1330[vs (ph-NO2)], 1225 [v (C–O)], 920 [v (C–N)], 783 [v (benzene)] and 702 [δ (benzene)].

X-ray crystal structure determination

A Siemens P4 diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) was applied for structure analyses of [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n. The data were collected at 293(2) K using ϕ and ω scan modes. The programs SHELXS-97 [24] and SHELXL-97 [25] were used for structure determination and refinement. The structures were solved by direct methods, and all non-hydrogen atoms were obtained from the difference Fourier map and subjected to anisotropic refinement by full-matrix least squares on F2. All hydrogen atoms of title complex were added geometrically or positioned by Difference Fourier synthesis and refined isotropically. Detailed information concerning crystallographic data collection and structure refinement is summarized in Table 1.

Results and discussionsThe crystal structure description of [CsNa(TNR)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub>

The least unsymmetrical unit structure of [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n is shown in Fig. 1, in which displacement ellipsoids are drawn at the 30% probability level. Selected bonds lengths and angles are listed in Table 2. The structure reveals that this complex contains two different central metal atoms: cesium (I) and sodium (I), which are connected through three different oxygen atoms: the oxygen atom of the nitro group O(3), the oxygen atom of phenolic hydroxyl group O(1)A, and the oxygen atom of water molecule O(10)D.

The coordination number of the central metal atom cesium (I) (Fig. 2) is 13, which is surrounded by eight oxygen atoms of nitro group [O(2), O(3), O(5)C, O(5)E, O(6)E, O(7)B, O(8)A, O(8)B] with distance in the range of 3.152(3)–3.669(3) Å, two oxygen atoms of phenolic hydroxyl group [O(1)A and O(4)C] and three oxygen atoms of coordinated water molecules [O(9), O(10), O(10)D]. The average distance of Cs–O bond (3.391 Å) around the 13-coordinated Cs(I) is larger than those around other 12 or eight coordinated Cs(I) [26–28]. This title complex is an irregular polyhedron, which is different from other cesium complexes [20].

Since Cs atom is an alkali metal atom with a larger atomic radius and more coordination ligands are able to stay around it, Cs atom displays a higher coordination number. All of the oxygen atoms in TNR have lone-paired electrons to be good coordination atoms, and TNR can serve as multidentate ligand.

The other central metal atom sodium (I) (Fig. 2) is surrounded by four oxygen atoms from TNR of phenolic hydroxyl group and nitro group [O(1)A, O(2)A, O(3), O(6)F] and two oxygen atoms from coordinated water molecules [O(10)D,O(11)] with distance in the range of 2.293(3)–2.513(3) Å. The average distance of Na–O bond is 2.395 Å. The bond angles of O (1)A–Na–O (11), O (1)A–Na–O (2)A, O (10)D–Na–O (6)F, and O (10)A–Na–O (3) are 153.76(12)o, 69.87(10), 80.04(11), and 107.49(11), respectively. All of the above demonstrate that each sodium (I) center is coordinated by six oxygen atoms forming a distorted octahedron. It is noted that three oxo bridges are formed between the adjacent Cs(I) and Na(I) cations by the oxygen atoms from two TNR and one coordinated water molecules forming a binuclear complex.

In this crystal, five TNR anions are coordinated to each Cs (I) cation, and eight center metal cations including five Cs (I) and three Na(I) cations are coordinated to each TNR anion (Fig. 3). The oxygen atoms of the phenolic hydroxyl group and all the nitro groups of TNR anion participate in binding to Cs (I) and Na(I) simultaneously. At the same time, the center metal atoms take part in four-six-membered and two-four-membered chelate rings, which make an important contribution to the stability of the complex.

The molecular packing of [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n is shown in Fig. 4. The TNR molecular chains are interlaced with the cesium atoms acting as knots, and the network structure is a three-dimensional ionic polymer, formed by many metal-anion coordination bonds. The coordinated Cs cations and the TNR anions are linked by electrostatic interactions and also weak van der Waals forces. The six hydrogen atoms of three coordinated water molecules link to adjacent oxygen atoms to form intramolecular hydrogen bonds, whose parameters are shown in Table 3. Owing to all of these interactions, the title coordination polymer is formed of a three-dimensional network.

Thermal analysis

Thermal analysis has proved to be an indispensable analytical tool for the research and development of novel energetic materials. For chemical classes that contain some unstable functional groups (e.g. nitro groups) attached to an aromatic ring, nitro groups can decrease the decomposition temperature and increase heat generation. The DSC and TG-DTG curves of [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n are illustrated in Figs. 5 and 6, respectively. There is only one distinct exothermic peak in the DSC curve. Three weight losses in the TG curve can be recognized between 50 and 500 °C.

The first one occurs from 63.6 to 126.3 °C with a weight loss of 7.6% of the initial weight, corresponding to the endothermic process on DSC. It indicates that about two coordinated water molecules are lost and the third water molecule is lost until the temperature reaches 241.2 °C. The weight loss of this process is about 9.9% of the initial weight which is close to the theoretic weight loss of 10.2%. This process is confirmed by the FT-IR spectrum of the residue at 241.2 °C with the disappearance of the characteristic absorption of O–H at 3451 cm−1.

The second weight loss of 30.4% occurs from 241.2 to 333.3 °C. It was shown that the above residue gives out a large amount of heat at high heating rate. The IR spectrum of the residue at 333.3 °C indicates that the characteristic absorption of nitro groups (1330, 1526 cm−1) and benzene ring (1622, 1473, 1395, 783 cm−1) disappears accounting for the elimination of nitro groups and decomposition of benzene ring. At the same time, the residue turns into the noncrystalline inorganic mixture in this process.

The last exothermic process occurs in the range of 336.5–390.0 °C. There is a mass loss of 5.8% corresponding to this temperature range in the TG-DTG curves. The mass of the final residue is 47.2% of the initial mass, coincident with the calculating value of Cs2CO3 and Na2CO3, 46.3%, and some carbon. The bands at 1448 and 885 cm−1 in the FT-IR spectrum of the residue at 390.0 °C prove that the final residue is Cs2CO3 and Na2CO3 [29].

Conclusion

A new hetero-bimetallic coordination polymer, cesium, and sodium complex of styphnate trihydrate [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n was synthesized by the reaction of cesium nitrate solution with sodium styphnate. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals the presence of a Cs(I) center with unusual coordination number 13 and a Na(I) with a distorted octahedron coordination environment in the polymeric chain. Owing to the three-dimensional structure, the thermal analysis indicated that the complex is relatively thermally stable.

Supplementary material

Crystallographic data for the structure has been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center as supplementary publication, CCDC No. 704680. Copies of the data can be obtained, free of charge, on application to CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK, (Fax:+44-1223-336033 or e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

The bond angles of O (1)A-Na-O (11), O (1)A-Na-O (2)A, O (10)D-Na-O (6)F, and O (10)A-Na-O (3) are 153.76(12)o, 69.87(10), 80.04(11), and 107.49(11), respectively. All of the above demonstrate that each sodium (I) center is coordinated by six oxygen atoms forming a distorted octahedron. It is noted that three oxo bridges are formed between the adjacent Cs(I) and Na(I) cations by the oxygen atoms from two TNR and one coordinated water molecules forming a binuclear complex.In this crystal, five TNR anions are coordinated to each Cs (I) cation, and eight center metal cations including five Cs (I) and three Na(I) cations are coordinated to each TNR anion (Fig. 3). The oxygen atoms of the phenolic hydroxyl group and all the nitro groups of TNR anion participate in binding to Cs (I) and Na(I) simultaneously. At the same time, the center metal atoms take part in four-six-membered and two-four-membered chelate rings, which make an important contribution to the stability of the complex.The molecular packing of [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n is shown in Fig. 4. The TNR molecular chains are interlaced with the cesium atoms acting as knots, and the network structure is a three-dimensional ionic polymer, formed by many metal-anion coordination bonds. The coordinated Cs cations and the TNR anions are linked by electrostatic interactions and also weak van der Waals forces. The six hydrogen atoms of three coordinated water molecules link to adjacent oxygen atoms to form intramolecular hydrogen bonds, whose parameters are shown in Table 3. Owing to all of these interactions, the title coordination polymer is formed of a three-dimensional network.Thermal analysisThermal analysis has proved to be an indispensable analytical tool for the research and development of novel energetic materials. For chemical classes that contain some unstable functional groups (e.g. nitro groups) attached to an aromatic ring, nitro groups can decrease the decomposition temperature and increase heat generation. The DSC and TG-DTG curves of [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n are illustrated in Figs. 5 and 6, respectively. There is only one distinct exothermic peak in the DSC curve. Three weight losses in the TG curve can be recognized between 50 and 500 °C.The first one occurs from 63.6 to 126.3 °C with a weight loss of 7.6% of the initial weight, corresponding to the endothermic process on DSC. It indicates that about two coordinated water molecules are lost and the third water molecule is lost until the temperature reaches 241.2 °C. The weight loss of this process is about 9.9% of the initial weight which is close to the theoretic weight loss of 10.2%. This process is confirmed by the FT-IR spectrum of the residue at 241.2 °C with the disappearance of the characteristic absorption of O-H at 3451 cm-1.The second weight loss of 30.4% occurs from 241.2 to 333.3 °C. It was shown that the above residue gives out a large amount of heat at high heating rate. The IR spectrum of the residue at 333.3 °C indicates that the characteristic absorption of nitro groups (1330, 1526 cm-1) and benzene ring (1622, 1473, 1395, 783 cm-1) disappears accounting for the elimination of nitro groups and decomposition of benzene ring. At the same time, the residue turns into the noncrystalline inorganic mixture in this process.The last exothermic process occurs in the range of 336.5-390.0 °C. There is a mass loss of 5.8% corresponding to this temperature range in the TG-DTG curves. The mass of the final residue is 47.2% of the initial mass, coincident with the calculating value of Cs2CO3 and Na2CO3, 46.3%, and some carbon. The bands at 1448 and 885 cm-1 in the FT-IR spectrum of the residue at 390.0 °C prove that the final residue is Cs2CO3 and Na2CO3 [29].Therefore, the decomposition pathway of the title compound can be [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n was synthesized by the reaction of cesium nitrate solution with sodium styphnate. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals the presence of a Cs(I) center with unusual coordination number 13 and a Na(I) with a distorted octahedron coordination environment in the polymeric chain. Owing to the three-dimensional structure, the thermal analysis indicated that the complex is relatively thermally stable.Supplementary materialCrystallographic data for the structure has been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center as supplementary publication, CCDC No. 704680. elements.content: A new hetero-bimetallic coordination polymer, cesium, and sodium complex of styphnate trihydrate [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n (TNR: 2,4,6-trinitroresorcinol dianion, the dianion of styphnic acid) was synthesized. The title complex was characterized by X-ray single crystal diffraction, element analysis, FT-IR, DSC, TG-DTG studies. In the title polymer molecule, the cesium cation is coordinated by 13 oxygen atoms: three originated from the water molecule and the others are from the nitro group and the phenolic hydroxyl group of TNR; the sodium cation is surrounded by six oxygen atoms from water molecules and TNR forming a distorted octahedron. The coordination polymer crystal was formed by the bridging ligands of water molecules and TNR connected with different cesium and sodium cations.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A new hetero-bimetallic coordination polymer, cesium, and sodium complex of styphnate trihydrate [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n (TNR: 2,4,6-trinitroresorcinol dianion, the dianion of styphnic acid) was synthesized. The title complex was characterized by X-ray single crystal diffraction, element analysis, FT-IR, DSC, TG-DTG studies. In the title polymer molecule, the cesium cation is coordinated by 13 oxygen atoms: three originated from the water molecule and the others are from the nitro group and the phenolic hydroxyl group of TNR; the sodium cation is surrounded by six oxygen atoms from water molecules and TNR forming a distorted octahedron. The coordination polymer crystal was formed by the bridging ligands of water molecules and TNR connected with different cesium and sodium cations.

elements.content: 2,4,6-Trinitro-1,3-benzenediol (2,4,6-trinitro-resorcinol) is also known as styphnic acid. According to its structure, explosive power, and sensitivity, it is similar to picric acid [1]. It and its metal salts are important military and commercial explosive materials. In particular, lead, barium, silver, and potassium salts of 2,4,6-trinitro-resorcinol have good detonating properties and are sensitive to flames and impact, therefore, they can be used as ingredient in the primary explosives, delay composition, ignition composition, and percussion composition [2]. A considerable amount of research about the structure and properties the salts of 2,4,6-trinitro-resorcinol have been done during the last 40 years [3–18].
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

2,4,6-Trinitro-1,3-benzenediol (2,4,6-trinitro-resorcinol) is also known as styphnic acid. According to its structure, explosive power, and sensitivity, it is similar to picric acid [1]. It and its metal salts are important military and commercial explosive materials. In particular, lead, barium, silver, and potassium salts of 2,4,6-trinitro-resorcinol have good detonating properties and are sensitive to flames and impact, therefore, they can be used as ingredient in the primary explosives, delay composition, ignition composition, and percussion composition [2]. A considerable amount of research about the structure and properties the salts of 2,4,6-trinitro-resorcinol have been done during the last 40 years [3-18].

elements.content: The previous research works are mainly focused on the heavy metal complex of styphnic acid which is widely used in propellants and primary explosives. However, there are more or less shortcomings with them, such as serious heavy metal pollution and high static sensitivity. In order to explore environment friendly initiating compositions, people gradually emphasized particularly on the alkaline and alkali-earth metal salts of nitrogen-rich acid [17–23]. In our recent research works, we synthesized the potassium, sodium, barium salts of 2,4,6-trinitro-resorcinol and trinitrophloroglucinol, determined their crystal structures [15–19]. Here, we prepared a new hetero-bimetallic complex of styphnate, [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n, cultured its single crystal, determined its molecular structure and crystal structure, put forward a thermal decomposition mechanism of the title compound from DSC, TG-DTG, and FT-IR results.

Experimental

Materials and instruments

2,4,6-Trinitro-resorcinol is a commercial product and has been purified by recrystallization in distilled water. Other materials and reagents used in the experiments are analytically pure.

Infrared spectrum was recorded on Bruker Equinox-55 spectrometer in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 using KBr pellets with the resolution of 4 cm-1. Elemental analyses were performed on an 1106 full-automatic trace element analyzer.

elements.content:
The single crystal structure was determined by Siemens P4 diffractometers with graphite-monochromated Mo Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K.

TG-DTG measurements were carried out on a Pyris-1 differential scanning calorimeter and thermogravimeter under nitrogen atmosphere. The heating rate was 10 °C/min for TG. The conditions of DSC were as follows: sample mass about 1.0 mg, heated rate 10 °C/min, static air atmosphere, α-Al2O3 reference sample.

elements.content: Sodium styphnate solution was prepared by slowly adding sodium carbonate (5 mmol) into equivalent diluted aqueous styphnic acid (100 mL, 0.1 mol/L) by heating and agitating at 60 °C for 30 min. After the total reaction, the mixture was cooled and filtered. The obtained liquor was added dropwise into aqueous cesium nitrate solution (50 mL, 0.1 mol/L) with violent stirring. The mixture reacted at 75 °C for 45 min until yellowish precipitate was formed. The precipitate was collected by filtration and washed with distilled water. Dissolve the powder in hot distilled water, filtrate, and then cool the solution to crystallize the final product and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 2 h. A yellowish powder of [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n was obtained in a yield of 65% based styphnic acid.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the title compound

Sodium styphnate solution was prepared by slowly adding sodium carbonate (5 mmol) into equivalent diluted aqueous styphnic acid (100 mL, 0.1 mol/L) by heating and agitating at 60 °C for 30 min. After the total reaction, the mixture was cooled and filtered. The obtained liquor was added dropwise into aqueous cesium nitrate solution (50 mL, 0.1 mol/L) with violent stirring. The mixture reacted at 75 °C for 45 min until yellowish precipitate was formed. The precipitate was collected by filtration and washed with distilled water. Dissolve the powder in hot distilled water, filtrate, and then cool the solution to crystallize the final product and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 2 h. A yellowish powder of [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n was obtained in a yield of 65% based styphnic acid.

elements.content:
The yellowish precipitate was recrystallized with distilled water and kept at room temperature for 2 weeks to obtain the single crystals for X-ray measurement.

elements.content: A Siemens P4 diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) was applied for structure analyses of [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n. The data were collected at 293(2) K using ϕ and ω scan modes. The programs SHELXS-97 [24] and SHELXL-97 [25] were used for structure determination and refinement. The structures were solved by direct methods, and all non-hydrogen atoms were obtained from the difference Fourier map and subjected to anisotropic refinement by full-matrix least squares on F2. All hydrogen atoms of title complex were added geometrically or positioned by Difference Fourier synthesis and refined isotropically. Detailed information concerning crystallographic data collection and structure refinement is summarized in Table 1.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystal structure determination

A Siemens P4 diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) was applied for structure analyses of [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n. The data were collected at 293(2) K using ϕ and ω scan modes. The programs SHELXS-97 [24] and SHELXL-97 [25] were used for structure determination and refinement. The structures were solved by direct methods, and all non-hydrogen atoms were obtained from the difference Fourier map and subjected to anisotropic refinement by full-matrix least squares on F2. All hydrogen atoms of title complex were added geometrically or positioned by Difference Fourier synthesis and refined isotropically. Detailed information concerning crystallographic data collection and structure refinement is summarized in Table 1.

The least unsymmetrical unit structure of [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n is shown in Fig. 1, in which displacement ellipsoids are drawn at the 30% probability level. Selected bonds lengths and angles are listed in Table 2. The structure reveals that this complex contains two different central metal atoms: cesium (I) and sodium (I), which are connected through three different oxygen atoms: the oxygen atom of the nitro group O(3), the oxygen atom of phenolic hydroxyl group O(1)A, and the oxygen atom of water molecule O(10)D.

Results and discussions

The crystal structure description of [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n

The least unsymmetrical unit structure of [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n is shown in Fig. 1, in which displacement ellipsoids are drawn at the 30% probability level. Selected bonds lengths and angles are listed in Table 2. The structure reveals that this complex contains two different central metal atoms: cesium (I) and sodium (I), which are connected through three different oxygen atoms: the oxygen atom of the nitro group O(3), the oxygen atom of phenolic hydroxyl group O(1)A, and the oxygen atom of water molecule O(10)D.

The coordination number of the central metal atom cesium (I) (Fig. 2) is 13, which is surrounded by eight oxygen atoms of nitro group [O(2), O(3), O(5)C, O(5)E, O(6)E, O(7)B, O(8)A, O(8)B] with distance in the range of 3.152(3)–3.669(3) Å, two oxygen atoms of phenolic hydroxyl group [O(1)A and O(4)C] and three oxygen atoms of coordinated water molecules [O(9), O(10), O(10)D]. The average distance of Cs–O bond (3.391 Å) around the 13-coordinated Cs(I) is larger than those around other 12 or eight coordinated Cs(I) [26–28]. This title complex is an irregular polyhedron, which is different from other cesium complexes [20].
elements.clean_text: The coordination number of the central metal atom cesium (I) (Fig. 2) is 13, which is surrounded by eight oxygen atoms of nitro group [O(2), O(3), O(5)C, O(5)E, O(6)E, O(7)B, O(8)A, O(8)B] with distance in the range of 3.152(3)-3.669(3) Å, two oxygen atoms of phenolic hydroxyl group [O(1)A and O(4)C] and three oxygen atoms of coordinated water molecules [O(9), O(10), O(10)D]. The average distance of Cs-O bond (3.391 Å) around the 13-coordinated Cs(I) is larger than those around other 12 or eight coordinated Cs(I) [26-28]. This title complex is an irregular polyhedron, which is different from other cesium complexes [20].

elements.content: Since Cs atom is an alkali metal atom with a larger atomic radius and more coordination ligands are able to stay around it, Cs atom displays a higher coordination number. All of the oxygen atoms in TNR have lone-paired electrons to be good coordination atoms, and TNR can serve as multidentate ligand.

All of the oxygen atoms in TNR have lone-paired electrons to be good coordination atoms, and TNR can serve as multidentate ligand.

elements.content: The other central metal atom sodium (I) (Fig. 2) is surrounded by four oxygen atoms from TNR of phenolic hydroxyl group and nitro group [O(1)A, O(2)A, O(3), O(6)F] and two oxygen atoms from coordinated water molecules [O(10)D,O(11)] with distance in the range of 2.293(3)–2.513(3) Å. The average distance of Na–O bond is 2.395 Å. The bond angles of O (1)A–Na–O (11), O (1)A–Na–O (2)A, O (10)D–Na–O (6)F, and O (10)A–Na–O (3) are 153.76(12)o, 69.87(10), 80.04(11), and 107.49(11), respectively. All of the above demonstrate that each sodium (I) center is coordinated by six oxygen atoms forming a distorted octahedron. It is noted that three oxo bridges are formed between the adjacent Cs(I) and Na(I) cations by the oxygen atoms from two TNR and one coordinated water molecules forming a binuclear complex.

elements.content: In this crystal, five TNR anions are coordinated to each Cs (I) cation, and eight center metal cations including five Cs (I) and three Na(I) cations are coordinated to each TNR anion (Fig. 3). The oxygen atoms of the phenolic hydroxyl group and all the nitro groups of TNR anion participate in binding to Cs (I) and Na(I) simultaneously. At the same time, the center metal atoms take part in four-six-membered and two-four-membered chelate rings, which make an important contribution to the stability of the complex.

elements.content: The molecular packing of [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n is shown in Fig. 4. The TNR molecular chains are interlaced with the cesium atoms acting as knots, and the network structure is a three-dimensional ionic polymer, formed by many metal-anion coordination bonds. The coordinated Cs cations and the TNR anions are linked by electrostatic interactions and also weak van der Waals forces. The six hydrogen atoms of three coordinated water molecules link to adjacent oxygen atoms to form intramolecular hydrogen bonds, whose parameters are shown in Table 3. Owing to all of these interactions, the title coordination polymer is formed of a three-dimensional network.

Thermal analysis has proved to be an indispensable analytical tool for the research and development of novel energetic materials. For chemical classes that contain some unstable functional groups (e.g. nitro groups) attached to an aromatic ring, nitro groups can decrease the decomposition temperature and increase heat generation. The DSC and TG-DTG curves of [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n are illustrated in Figs. 5 and 6, respectively. There is only one distinct exothermic peak in the DSC curve. Three weight losses in the TG curve can be recognized between 50 and 500 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal analysis

Thermal analysis has proved to be an indispensable analytical tool for the research and development of novel energetic materials. For chemical classes that contain some unstable functional groups (e.g. nitro groups) attached to an aromatic ring, nitro groups can decrease the decomposition temperature and increase heat generation. The DSC and TG-DTG curves of [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n are illustrated in Figs. 5 and 6, respectively. There is only one distinct exothermic peak in the DSC curve. Three weight losses in the TG curve can be recognized between 50 and 500 °C.

elements.content: The first one occurs from 63.6 to 126.3 °C with a weight loss of 7.6% of the initial weight, corresponding to the endothermic process on DSC. It indicates that about two coordinated water molecules are lost and the third water molecule is lost until the temperature reaches 241.2 °C. The weight loss of this process is about 9.9% of the initial weight which is close to the theoretic weight loss of 10.2%. This process is confirmed by the FT-IR spectrum of the residue at 241.2 °C with the disappearance of the characteristic absorption of O–H at 3451 cm−1.

elements.content: The second weight loss of 30.4% occurs from 241.2 to 333.3 °C. It was shown that the above residue gives out a large amount of heat at high heating rate. The IR spectrum of the residue at 333.3 °C indicates that the characteristic absorption of nitro groups (1330, 1526 cm−1) and benzene ring (1622, 1473, 1395, 783 cm−1) disappears accounting for the elimination of nitro groups and decomposition of benzene ring. At the same time, the residue turns into the noncrystalline inorganic mixture in this process.

elements.content: A new hetero-bimetallic coordination polymer, cesium, and sodium complex of styphnate trihydrate [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n was synthesized by the reaction of cesium nitrate solution with sodium styphnate. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals the presence of a Cs(I) center with unusual coordination number 13 and a Na(I) with a distorted octahedron coordination environment in the polymeric chain. Owing to the three-dimensional structure, the thermal analysis indicated that the complex is relatively thermally stable.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A new hetero-bimetallic coordination polymer, cesium, and sodium complex of styphnate trihydrate [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n was synthesized by the reaction of cesium nitrate solution with sodium styphnate. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals the presence of a Cs(I) center with unusual coordination number 13 and a Na(I) with a distorted octahedron coordination environment in the polymeric chain. Owing to the three-dimensional structure, the thermal analysis indicated that the complex is relatively thermally stable.

cln_elements.content: Sodium styphnate solution was prepared by slowly adding sodium carbonate (5 mmol) into equivalent diluted aqueous styphnic acid (100 mL, 0.1 mol/L) by heating and agitating at 60 °C for 30 min. After the total reaction, the mixture was cooled and filtered. The obtained liquor was added dropwise into aqueous cesium nitrate solution (50 mL, 0.1 mol/L) with violent stirring. The mixture reacted at 75 °C for 45 min until yellowish precipitate was formed. The precipitate was collected by filtration and washed with distilled water. Dissolve the powder in hot distilled water, filtrate, and then cool the solution to crystallize the final product and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 2 h. A yellowish powder of [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n was obtained in a yield of 65% based styphnic acid.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the title compound

Sodium styphnate solution was prepared by slowly adding sodium carbonate (5 mmol) into equivalent diluted aqueous styphnic acid (100 mL, 0.1 mol/L) by heating and agitating at 60 °C for 30 min. After the total reaction, the mixture was cooled and filtered. The obtained liquor was added dropwise into aqueous cesium nitrate solution (50 mL, 0.1 mol/L) with violent stirring. The mixture reacted at 75 °C for 45 min until yellowish precipitate was formed. The precipitate was collected by filtration and washed with distilled water. Dissolve the powder in hot distilled water, filtrate, and then cool the solution to crystallize the final product and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 2 h. A yellowish powder of [CsNa(TNR)(H2O)3]n was obtained in a yield of 65% based styphnic acid.

The first one occurs from 63.6 to 126.3 °C with a weight loss of 7.6% of the initial weight, corresponding to the endothermic process on DSC. It indicates that about two coordinated water molecules are lost and the third water molecule is lost until the temperature reaches 241.2 °C. The weight loss of this process is about 9.9% of the initial weight which is close to the theoretic weight loss of 10.2%. This process is confirmed by the FT-IR spectrum of the residue at 241.2 °C with the disappearance of the characteristic absorption of O–H at 3451 cm−1.

The second weight loss of 30.4% occurs from 241.2 to 333.3 °C. It was shown that the above residue gives out a large amount of heat at high heating rate. The IR spectrum of the residue at 333.3 °C indicates that the characteristic absorption of nitro groups (1330, 1526 cm−1) and benzene ring (1622, 1473, 1395, 783 cm−1) disappears accounting for the elimination of nitro groups and decomposition of benzene ring. At the same time, the residue turns into the noncrystalline inorganic mixture in this process.

The last exothermic process occurs in the range of 336.5–390.0 °C. There is a mass loss of 5.8% corresponding to this temperature range in the TG-DTG curves. The mass of the final residue is 47.2% of the initial mass, coincident with the calculating value of Cs2CO3 and Na2CO3, 46.3%, and some carbon. The bands at 1448 and 885 cm−1 in the FT-IR spectrum of the residue at 390.0 °C prove that the final residue is Cs2CO3 and Na2CO3 [29].
